Succeed Insurance has specified that the persons involved section of a claim should have a page listing the officials associated with the claim. Information should include the official's name, title, and the number of any filed report. My first step will be to create a page called Claim Officials. In this demo, I shall create the page. I will add it to the UI in a subsequent demo. So, from the Configuration node, I expand Config. Config. Page configuration. Page configuration. Claim. Claim.  I will put the Claim Officials page in the parties involved node, so I right-click the node. And select New. PCF file. The file type of the PCF file will be Page. I will use a suffix of underscore SI for Succeed Insurance, so the full name of the page is Claim Officials underscore SI. I click OK to create the page. The page appears in red, because it has not yet been configured. A list of errors appears below. To begin configuring the page, I click its name. A title is required. I will use a display key, which I have created prior to this demonstration. Next, I create a variable to hold the page. I will hold the claim to which the officials are related. In the Variables tab, I click this button to create a new variable. The variable's name is Claim, with a small c. Its entity type is Claim, with a capital C. The page requires a panel ref to hold data. I click the panel ref icon. And then click in the page to drop a panel ref there. Note that when I add the panel ref, a screen is automatically created to contain it. The panel ref now needs a list view to display the list of officials. There is a list view in the Lost Details node that might serve the purpose. I double-click the editable officials list view to open it. This list view holds the data that is required, so I can use it. I return to the Claim Officials page. I click the panel ref to open its properties. In the definition property of the panel ref I enter the name of the list view, passing it the claim variable. I click the panel ref to open it. Users should be able to edit this list. I select the page. And set its can edit property. And its can visit property both to true. Next, I select the screen. And set its editable property to true. Then, I do the same for the panel ref. From the tool box, I select the edit buttons widget. And drop it into the screen. It is important that the edit buttons go onto the screen, not the page or the panel ref. The edit buttons do not require configuration at this time. Then I select an iterator buttons widget. And drop it onto the panel ref. The iterator buttons require an iterator, so I select them to open their properties. In the iterator property, I type the name of the list view, twice, separated by a period. Finally, I need to provide the page with an entry point, so that the user interface will be able to navigate to it. In the entry points tab, I create a new entry point. The entry point's name must match the name of the page. It needs a parameter to pass the claim to the page from the calling page. To see the layout of the page I have created, I step off it. And then back onto it. The page still has an error, because I haven't added it to a location group yet. I will not be able to see my work in the user interface until I've done so. That is the subject of the next demonstration. This concludes the configuring page components demonstration.

The ClaimCenter line of business model consists of six specialized type lists. The highest level of these type lists is loss type. The loss type ties together policies, coverages, and claims that deal with similar losses. In the base application, there are five loss types, auto, general liability, property, travel, and workers' compensation. Next is the LOB code, or line of business code, type list. This type list is more granular than loss type, and is mostly used for reporting purposes. It has a many to one relationship to loss type. That is, many LOB codes may refer to the same loss type. For example, the commercial property line and the homeowner's line both refer to the property loss type. The policy type type list refers to the same loss type. The coverage type type type list of specific products offered by an insurer. This has a many-to-many relationship to LOB code. That is, one policy type may refer to one or more LOB codes, and any given LOB code may refer back to one or more policy types. For example, the commercial package policy type. And the commercial property policy type both refer to the commercial property line of business. The commercial package policy type also refers to other lines of business. The coverage type type list. specifies something that a policy may indemnify. Again, this is in a many-to-many relationship with policy type. I'm going to skip to the sixth type list, exposure type, for a moment. Recall that an exposure is a pairing of a coverage and a claimant, which tracks potential payments for a claim. The exposure type in the LOB model determines the information to gather about each exposure. The coverage subtype is essentially a mapping between one coverage type and one exposure type. That is, it says this type of coverage can cover this type of exposure. The mapping need not be unique. The same coverage type and exposure type can be paired by more than one coverage subtype to handle different circumstances. Now, let's take a look at how the type lists of the line of business model work together in the data dictionary. Let's navigate down the list of type lists. To coverage type, which is a fairly typical example. Scrolling down, we can see a rather large collection of type codes. If we navigate to a typical type code, we see that each type code has a set of categories associated with it. These refer downward in the line of business model to the coverage subtype, and also upward to the policy type. Knowing whether a given category item refers upward or downward depends on familiarity with the line of business model. There is also a category for source system, the system from which the data about coverage types comes. This is typically a policy administration system. This appears on all the LOB types except loss type and exposure type. This is because loss type and exposure type are unique to claim center, while the other components of the LOB model are typically populated from an insurer's PAS, such as policy center. You can easily navigate from one level of the hierarchy to another by clicking on these categories. I'll navigate down to the coverage subtype, then back up to the coverage type, from there to a policy type. Commercial package has a lot of coverage types, but we'll continue on up to one of its associated LOB codes, and on up to a loss type. Now let's see how these lists are configured in Studio. If I expand a typical coverage type node, this one is accounts receivable for off-premises property. I see that it has three nodes beneath it, children, parents, and other categories. Expanding them. I see that these are the same categories I saw in the data dictionary. I'm currently looking at this in the line of business tab. If I switch to the type list tab, and expand a typical node. It just lists related type lists, without any division between the various types of category. Looking at the incoming categories tab, and expanding a node. I see that coverage subtype and policy type are not the only type lists that refer to coverage type. Cove term pattern, cost category, and line category all refer to this entry. While in the outgoing categories tab, we see that coverage subtypes, and policy types are visible here, but no others, because coverage type does not refer out or to any other type lists. Except, of course, for source system. This is not true for all line of business type lists. Policy type, for example, refers not only to lob code, coverage type, and source system, but to policy tab, but to policy tab, and internal policy type. Looking at loss type, it only has a children node, no parents or other categories nodes. Similarly, in the exposure type type code, there are parents and other categories nodes, but no children node. The other category here is an incident. An incident type is required for all exposure types. This concludes the exploring line of business type lists demonstration.

And paste the line I copied. Now I simply change the exposure type to TC underscore electronics underscore SI. And paste the line in the block of the UI. And paste the line in the block of the UI. At this point it is a good idea to explicitly save my work. I need to display the details of the incident type. I drill down on page configuration. PCF. Claim. And new exposure. Exposure. I look at the existing general damage mode of the new exposure detail view. It contains the data needed for the electronics exposure. So I copy it. And paste a copy into the same node. I type the name of the mode, electronics underscore SI. And save the new PCF file. Once again, I'll save my work. Now I start the server in debug mode. In this demo, I'll review claim intake from a user's perspective, and at the same time take a look at it from behind the scenes in Studio's PCF files. I'm logged on as Darlene Olson, an adjuster. I receive a call from Jennifer Albee at Lennar Construction, reporting that a worker has been injured, so I start a new claim. Notice, by the way, that the title says that this is step 1. I search for the Lennar Construction policy. There is only one policy matching this search, so it is automatically selected. Because it is a worker's compensation policy, the header changes, indicating that this is step 1 of 4. I'll type CTRL-SHIFT-I to view the details of the PCF behind this step. The screen I am viewing is part of the new claim wizard, also called the FNAL wizard. The screen is the FNAL wizard underscore find policy screen. Note that the naming can be used as part of the new claim wizard, also called the FNAL wizard. The convention for the screens in a wizard is wizard name underscore screen name. Let's look at this in Studio. Looking at this screen, I notice some fields called shared section modes, which I'll explain in the next demo. But what I want to show you right now, is that, if I select search in this field, I now see the fields I saw in the UI. Speaking of the UI, Ms. Albee tells me that the injury occurred at the beginning of today's morning shift, at 8am. Moving on to the next page of the new claim wizard. The injury occurred at the company's headquarters. Ms. Albee is the supervisor of the injured employee, 1 Edward Teach. I add Mr. Teach. I add Mr. Teach as the injured employee. Ms. Albee has also provided me with a total of statements, Mr.Teach's social security number. I'll type Alt Shift I again. I'm still viewing the FNUL wizard, and now the screen is the basic info screen. At this point, I want to show you the structure of the wizard itself. I open FNULwizard.pcf. Structurally, a wizard is simply a list of steps. A wizard has some interesting properties. The first is menu actions. You may recall from location groups that this defines the actions menu that will appear. It also has the standard claim info bar and tab bar. The cancel warning property specifies the text of a pop-up message that appears if you cancel the claim before finishing the wizard. This message should be stored as a display key. The wizard goes through the steps in order. You can create step sets that group steps, so that you can make them available or unavailable together. The full wizard step set is the main body of the FNUL wizard. Note that its visibility property is true only if the old wizard step property is false, which is the default. This exists for backwards compatibility. Within the step set, the individual steps have their own visible and available conditions. The only step for which these do not simply default to true is the services step, which does not make sense for some policy types. The services step determines its availability by a property coded in the wizard. The code for a servicer's step available checks against a list of lost types for which a services step makes sense. In the base configuration, these include auto and property. Each step in the wizard has a screen property. This identifies the signature of a screen which will be displayed when the wizard reaches that step. Each step also has a title property, which references a display key. Note that this display key takes variables that reference the current step number and the total number of steps for the wizard. Finally, let's look at two special types of step. The first is the quick claim step. A quick claim step bypasses the normal set of steps and inputs the essential information on one screen. The quick claim step has a property called condition, which determines whether it is available. For example, the quick claim auto step is available only if the loss type is auto. The decision to use the quick claim step is made by the user in the first step of the wizard. Some steps are independent of the wizard's built-in sequencing. They are available from anywhere in the wizard, except for the first step, where the policy is found. Independent steps have their independent property set to true. Independent steps are usually grouped in a special step set called an independent wizard step set, which appears at the end of the wizard steps. Grouping in this manner is a recommended standard, but not required. Any step marked as independent will be an independent step. The independent steps for the FNAL wizard include parties involved, policy, documents, and notes. This concludes our tour of wizard structure, so I'll cancel the claim now. This ends the wizard structure demonstration.                  DEMONSTRATION  DEMONSTRATION           DEMONSTRATION Thank you.

Depending on the value of page mode, a Boolean variable of the wizard, the value of this property will be either Search or Create. The value of the mode property must match the mode suffix of one of the PCF files that match the panel ref's def property. Let's look at a slightly more complicated example. If I look at FNUL wizard underscore new lost details screen, I see that it has five modes. Four of them match the type codes for lost type, GL for general liability, PR for property, TRAV for travel insurance, and DUB-C for workers compensation. The fifth mode is default. The default screen is displayed if the mode property does not match any of the other modes, in this case, any lost type, such as auto, other than the four specified modes. Having a default mode ensures that no possible value of the mode property will go unmatched and cause a runtime error. Wizard step sets also have a mode property. However, that property is seldom used. This ends the modal PCF basics demonstration.
